Title: Anatomical organization of the primate amygdaloid complex

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Terminology for the accessory basal nucleus has been somewhat less variable than for the basal nucleus (Fig. 2) [In subprimates, the accessory basal nucleus has often been termed the basomedial nucleus (see Price et al., 1987), and this terminology has recently been applied to the monkey (Barbas and deOlmos, 1990) and the human (deOlmos, 1990). In primates, unfortunately, this usage may be confusing because many investigators have used the term basomedial (or mediobasal) for the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus.]. ...Lauer (1945), however, named this area the accessory basal nucleus and divided it into a lateral, large-celled portion and a medial, smaller-celled portion. These regions closely correspond to the magnocellular and parvicellular divisions, respectively, described by Price et al.(1987) and used in this chapter. Price et al. (1987) described an additional 'superficial division' of the accessory basal nucleus and Amaral and Bassett (1989) described a fourth division, the ventromedial division, which had distinctly higher levels of cholinergic markers. More recently, Pitkänen and Amaral (1991b) have evaluated the pattern of labeling of this region in preparations stained for the enzyme NADPH-diaphorase (NADPH-d). It became clear in this analysis that the region forerly called the superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus is more likely to be a rostral extension of the amygdalohippocampal area, and in this chapter the term superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus has been eliminated." (p. 11)

@InterMapRelations.Comments: It is said that ABs of AB89 and PRA87 are parts of APPC92's AHA and not of APPC92's AB. Therefore, it seems that APPC92-AB is subpart of PRA87-AB and AB89-AB. This also means that APPC92's AHA include AHA of AB89 and PRA87.

"Attempting to acknowledge the regional differences in the organization of the periamygdaloid cortex, Price et al. (1987) divided it into four subdivisions: PAC1, PAC2, PAC3, and PACs. Because the distinction between PAC1 and PACs was tenuous in some animals and because the two regions had very similar staining patterns for cholinergic markers, Amaral and Bassett (1989) used the term PACs to encompass PACs and PAC1; this modifications is followed in this chapter." (p. 14)

"Even a cursory survey of a Nissl-stained section through the lateral nucleus amply demonstrates that it is a cytoarchitectonically heterogeneous region. As many as six and as few as one subdivisions have been attributed to the primate lateral nucleus (Fig. 2; Johnston, 1923; Lauer, 1945; Jimenez-Castellanos, 1949; Koikegami, 1963). In this chapter, we use the nomenclature of Price et al. (1987) as slightly modified by Amaral and Bassett (1989). Thus, the lateral nucleus of the Macaca fascicularis monkey has been subdivided into dorsomedial and ventrolateral divisions (Table I, Fig. 1C) based largely on differences in Nissl and acetylcholinesterase (AChE) staining (Amaral and Bassett, 1989). ...Along the lateral edge of the lateral nucleus there are occasionally patches of tightly packed, small neurons which are encapsulated by fiber bundles emanating from the external capsule. These cell groups were called the lateral capsular nuclei by Amaral and Bassett (1989) and stained intensely for AChE and choline acetytransferase (ChAT)." (pp. 7,9)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: It should be noted that, contradictionary to the statement of APPC92, AB89 didn't mentioned or showed the dorsomedial subdivision of the lateral nucleus (Ldm).

"The term 'cortical nucleus' has also often been used to designate the area that we have labeled the periamygdaloid cortex (Fig. 2; Johnston, 1923; Lauer, 1945; Jimenez-Castellanos, 1949; Koikegami, 1963)." (p. 12) "Jimenez-Castellanos (1949) divided the cortical nucleus into superficial or 'periamygdaloid ' regions and deep or 'amygdaloid' regions. Taken together, he identified approximately 10 divisions in the general area that we have labeled as the periamygdaloid cortex." (p. 14)

(p. 12) "Johnston (1923) named the periamygdaloid cortex the 'cortical nucleus', a term that is perhaps even now most commonly applied to this region (see Fig.2). @InterMapRelations.Citation: "Both Lauer (1945) and Jimenez-Castellanos (1949) described a central nucleus which corresponds only to what we have called the lateral dvision of the central nucleus (Fig. 2). These authors considered what we have called the medial division of the central nucleus to be a caudal extension of the anterior amygdaloid area (which, in their descriptions, extended nearly to the caudal pole of the amygdala)." (p. 15)
@InterMapRelations.Comments: Comparing J49 with APPC92, it seems that APPC92-CEl is identical with J49-sApd, APPC92-CEm is identical with J49-sApv (see the citation, where sApv of J49 is mentioned as the 'caudal extension' of the anterior amygdaloid area) , and that APPC92-AAA is identical with J49-ClprA (J49 call the oral or rostral division of the anterior amygdaloid area the 'ClprA' area) . Comparing APPC92 with L45, it seems that APPC92-CEl is identical with the whole central amygdaloid nucleus as described by L45, APPC92-CEm is a subpart of L45's anterior amygdaloid area, that APPC92-AAA is a subpart of L45's anterior amygdaloid area, and that APPC92-CE is overlapping with L45's anterior amygdaloid area.

@InterMapRelations.Citation: "Modern terminology began with the description of Johnston (1923), who called what we have labeled the basal nucleus ' the lateral, large-celled part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus' . Johnston's basal nucleus actually comprised both the basal nucleus and the accessory basal nucleus as we have defined it. The accessory basal nucleus in our description was included in his ' medial, small-celled part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus '. Lauer (1945) departed from Johnston's nomenclature and used the term basal nucleus much as have done to refer to the lateral, large-celled part of Johnston's basal nucleus. Lauer further subdivided the basal nucleus into a dorsally located, lateral, large-celled part (which corresponds to the magnocellular division of Price etal., 1987) and a ventrally located, medial, small-celled part (equivalent to the parvicellular division of Price et al., 1987). Lauer noted that the most ventral aspect of his medial, small-celled part of the basal nucleus was distinct from the remainder of the nucleus and he called this area the ' superficial portion of medial part of basal amygdaloid nucleus' . This area corresponds to what we have called the paralaminar nucleus. There are still a variety of names applied to the monkey basal nucleus (Fig. 2). One common variant uses the terms "lateral basal" or "basolateral" when referring to the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus and the terms "medial basal" or "basomedial" when referring to the parvicellular division. ...Dorsal to the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus is the intermediate division. The cells here are larger, more densely packed, and more darkly stained than in the parvicellular division. The dorsoventral border between the parvicellular and intermediate divisions of the basal nucleus extend further dorsally on the lateral and medial edges of the nucleus. Price et al. (1987) did not distinguish the intermediate division. The intermediate division contains higher levels of the cholinergic markers than the parvicellular division but lower levels than in the magnocellular division (Amaral and Basset, 1989)." (p. 10)

One common variant uses the terms "lateral basal" or "basolateral" when referring to the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus and the terms "medial basal" or "basomedial" when referring to the parvicellular division. ...Dorsal to the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus is the intermediate division. The cells here are larger, more densely packed, and more darkly stained than in the parvicellular division. The dorsoventral border between the parvicellular and intermediate divisions of the basal nucleus extend further dorsally on the lateral and medial edges of the nucleus. Price et al. (1987) did not distinguish the intermediate division. The intermediate division contains higher levels of the cholinergic markers than the parvicellular division but lower levels than in the magnocellular division (Amaral and Basset, 1989)." (p. 10)

"Modern terminology began with the description of Johnston (1923), who called what we have labeled the basal nucleus ' the lateral, large-celled part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus' . Johnston's basal nucleus actually comprised both the basal nucleus and the accessory basal nucleus as we have defined it. The accessory basal nucleus in our description was included in his ' medial, small-celled part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus '. Lauer (1945) departed from Johnston's nomenclature and used the term basal nucleus much as have done to refer to the lateral, large-celled part of Johnston's basal nucleus. Lauer further subdivided the basal nucleus into a dorsally located, lateral, large-celled part (which corresponds to the magnocellular division of Price etal., 1987) and a ventrally located, medial, small-celled part (equivalent to the parvicellular division of Price et al., 1987). Lauer noted that the most ventral aspect of his medial, small-celled part of the basal nucleus was distinct from the remainder of the nucleus and he called this area the ' superficial portion of medial part of basal amygdaloid nucleus' . This area corresponds to what we have called the paralaminar nucleus. There are still a variety of names applied to the monkey basal nucleus (Fig. 2). One common variant uses the terms "lateral basal" or "basolateral" when referring to the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus and the terms "medial basal" or "basomedial" when referring to the parvicellular division. ...Dorsal to the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus is the intermediate division. The cells here are larger, more densely packed, and more darkly stained than in the parvicellular division. The dorsoventral border between the parvicellular and intermediate divisions of the basal nucleus extend further dorsally on the lateral and medial edges of the nucleus. Price et al. (1987) did not distinguish the intermediate division. The intermediate division contains higher levels of the cholinergic markers than the parvicellular division but lower levels than in the magnocellular division (Amaral and Basset, 1989)." (p. 10)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "Terminology for the accessory basal nucleus has been somewhat less variable than for the basal nucleus (Fig. 2) [In subprimates, the accessory basal nucleus has often been termed the basomedial nucleus (see Price et al., 1987), and this terminology has recently been applied to the monkey (Barbas and deOlmos, 1990) and the human (deOlmos, 1990). In primates, unfortunately, this usage may be confusing because many investigators have used the term basomedial (or mediobasal) for the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus.]. ...Lauer (1945), however, named this area the accessory basal nucleus and divided it into a lateral, large-celled portion and a medial, smaller-celled portion. These regions closely correspond to the magnocellular and parvicellular divisions, respectively, described by Price et al.(1987) and used in this chapter. Price et al. (1987) described an additional 'superficial division' of the accessory basal nucleus and Amaral and Bassett (1989) described a fourth division, the ventromedial division, which had distinctly higher levels of cholinergic markers. More recently, Pitkänen and Amaral (1991b) have evaluated the pattern of labeling of this region in preparations stained for the enzyme NADPH-diaphorase (NADPH-d). It became clear in this analysis that the region forerly called the superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus is more likely to be a rostral extension of the amygdalohippocampal area, and in this chapter the term superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus has been eliminated." (p. 11)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: It is said that ABs of AB89 and PRA87 are parts of APPC92's AHA and not of APPC92's AB. Therefore, it seems that APPC92-AB is subpart of PRA87-AB and AB89-AB. This also means that APPC92's AHA include AHA of AB89 and PRA87.

In primates, unfortunately, this usage may be confusing because many investigators have used the term basomedial (or mediobasal) for the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus.]. ...Lauer (1945), however, named this area the accessory basal nucleus and divided it into a lateral, large-celled portion and a medial, smaller-celled portion. These regions closely correspond to the magnocellular and parvicellular divisions, respectively, described by Price et al.(1987) and used in this chapter. Price et al. (1987) described an additional 'superficial division' of the accessory basal nucleus and Amaral and Bassett (1989) described a fourth division, the ventromedial division, which had distinctly higher levels of cholinergic markers. More recently, Pitkänen and Amaral (1991b) have evaluated the pattern of labeling of this region in preparations stained for the enzyme NADPH-diaphorase (NADPH-d). It became clear in this analysis that the region forerly called the superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus is more likely to be a rostral extension of the amygdalohippocampal area, and in this chapter the term superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus has been eliminated." (p. 11)

"Attempting to acknowledge the regional differences in the organization of the periamygdaloid cortex, Price et al. (1987) divided it into four subdivisions: PAC1, PAC2, PAC3, and PACs. Because the distinction between PAC1 and PACs was tenuous in some animals and because the two regions had very similar staining patterns for cholinergic markers, Amaral and Bassett (1989) used the term PACs to encompass PACs and PAC1; this modifications is followed in this chapter." (p. 14)

"Even a cursory survey of a Nissl-stained section through the lateral nucleus amply demonstrates that it is a cytoarchitectonically heterogeneous region. As many as six and as few as one subdivisions have been attributed to the primate lateral nucleus (Fig. 2; Johnston, 1923; Lauer, 1945; Jimenez-Castellanos, 1949; Koikegami, 1963). In this chapter, we use the nomenclature of Price et al. (1987) as slightly modified by Amaral and Bassett (1989). Thus, the lateral nucleus of the Macaca fascicularis monkey has been subdivided into dorsomedial and ventrolateral divisions (Table I, Fig. 1C) based largely on differences in Nissl and acetylcholinesterase (AChE) staining (Amaral and Bassett, 1989). ...Along the lateral edge of the lateral nucleus there are occasionally patches of tightly packed, small neurons which are encapsulated by fiber bundles emanating from the external capsule. These cell groups were called the lateral capsular nuclei by Amaral and Bassett (1989) and stained intensely for AChE and choline acetytransferase (ChAT)." (pp. 7,9)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: It should be noted that, contradictionary to the statement of APPC92, AB89 didn't mentioned or showed the dorsomedial subdivision of the lateral nucleus (Ldm).

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "Terminology for the accessory basal nucleus has been somewhat less variable than for the basal nucleus (Fig. 2) [In subprimates, the accessory basal nucleus has often been termed the basomedial nucleus (see Price et al., 1987), and this terminology has recently been applied to the monkey (Barbas and deOlmos, 1990) and the human (deOlmos, 1990). In primates, unfortunately, this usage may be confusing because many investigators have used the term basomedial (or mediobasal) for the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus.]. ...Lauer (1945), however, named this area the accessory basal nucleus and divided it into a lateral, large-celled portion and a medial, smaller-celled portion. These regions closely correspond to the magnocellular and parvicellular divisions, respectively, described by Price et al.(1987) and used in this chapter. Price et al. (1987) described an additional 'superficial division' of the accessory basal nucleus and Amaral and Bassett (1989) described a fourth division, the ventromedial division, which had distinctly higher levels of cholinergic markers. More recently, Pitkänen and Amaral (1991b) have evaluated the pattern of labeling of this region in preparations stained for the enzyme NADPH-diaphorase (NADPH-d). It became clear in this analysis that the region forerly called the superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus is more likely to be a rostral extension of the amygdalohippocampal area, and in this chapter the term superficial division of the accessory basal nucleus has been eliminated." (p. 11) "The anterior portion of the amygdalohippocampal area was previously named the superficial portion of the accessory basal nucleus (Price et al., 1987). " (p. 16)

"The term 'cortical nucleus' has also often been used to designate the area that we have labeled the periamygdaloid cortex (Fig. 2; Johnston, 1923; Lauer, 1945; Jimenez-Castellanos, 1949; Koikegami, 1963)." (p. 12) "Jimenez-Castellanos (1949) divided the cortical nucleus into superficial or 'periamygdaloid ' regions and deep or 'amygdaloid' regions. Taken together, he identified approximately 10 divisions in the general area that we have labeled as the periamygdaloid cortex." (p. 14)

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "Both Lauer (1945) and Jimenez-Castellanos (1949) described a central nucleus which corresponds only to what we have called the lateral dvision of the central nucleus (Fig. 2). These authors considered what we have called the medial division of the central nucleus to be a caudal extension of the anterior amygdaloid area (which, in their descriptions, extended nearly to the caudal pole of the amygdala)." (p. 15)
@InterMapRelations_clean.Comments: Comparing J49 with APPC92, it seems that APPC92-CEl is identical with J49-sApd, APPC92-CEm is identical with J49-sApv (see the citation, where sApv of J49 is mentioned as the 'caudal extension' of the anterior amygdaloid area) , and that APPC92-AAA is identical with J49-ClprA (J49 call the oral or rostral division of the anterior amygdaloid area the 'ClprA' area) . Comparing APPC92 with L45, it seems that APPC92-CEl is identical with the whole central amygdaloid nucleus as described by L45, APPC92-CEm is a subpart of L45's anterior amygdaloid area, that APPC92-AAA is a subpart of L45's anterior amygdaloid area, and that APPC92-CE is overlapping with L45's anterior amygdaloid area.

@InterMapRelations_clean.Citation: "Modern terminology began with the description of Johnston (1923), who called what we have labeled the basal nucleus ' the lateral, large-celled part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus' . Johnston's basal nucleus actually comprised both the basal nucleus and the accessory basal nucleus as we have defined it. The accessory basal nucleus in our description was included in his ' medial, small-celled part of the basal amygdaloid nucleus '. Lauer (1945) departed from Johnston's nomenclature and used the term basal nucleus much as have done to refer to the lateral, large-celled part of Johnston's basal nucleus. Lauer further subdivided the basal nucleus into a dorsally located, lateral, large-celled part (which corresponds to the magnocellular division of Price etal., 1987) and a ventrally located, medial, small-celled part (equivalent to the parvicellular division of Price et al., 1987). Lauer noted that the most ventral aspect of his medial, small-celled part of the basal nucleus was distinct from the remainder of the nucleus and he called this area the ' superficial portion of medial part of basal amygdaloid nucleus' . This area corresponds to what we have called the paralaminar nucleus. There are still a variety of names applied to the monkey basal nucleus (Fig. 2). One common variant uses the terms "lateral basal" or "basolateral" when referring to the magnocellular division of the basal nucleus and the terms "medial basal" or "basomedial" when referring to the parvicellular division. ...Dorsal to the parvicellular division of the basal nucleus is the intermediate division. The cells here are larger, more densely packed, and more darkly stained than in the parvicellular division. The dorsoventral border between the parvicellular and intermediate divisions of the basal nucleus extend further dorsally on the lateral and medial edges of the nucleus. Price et al. (1987) did not distinguish the intermediate division. The intermediate division contains higher levels of the cholinergic markers than the parvicellular division but lower levels than in the magnocellular division (Amaral and Basset, 1989)." (p. 10)
